title: I am scoring around 650 on the SAT Math section. How can I raise my math score to a 700? - Quora

response.answer_text: Answer the grid-in/student-response questions first. You can’t guess on those, so get those points before they’re lost. Underline everything that seems useful, somehow it helps me remember and often prevents me from needing to reread the question multiple times. Understand the different types of questions. The SAT follows a pretty regular format, and if you know exactly what each type of question is looking for, it will save you valuable time and help you not fall into the same traps (for example, questions where they give you different solution sets to choose from—e.g. {3,2} {3,2,1} {3}—they are often trying to test if you remember to check and see if your solution is extraneous; don’t rush on these ones and mistakenly assume your solutions are all correct, because they will rarely be). Don’t wait too long on one question, circle and come back later. I had trouble with letting answers go, but it is crucial. Look at the answers before you start solving, you might actually be finding the wrong type of solution because you misunderstood the question. Also sometimes the answers are somewhat obvious and it’s a waste of time to solve them (ex: convert this equation into point-slope, and then only one answer is in point-slope form—yes I have seen these). Of course taking practice tests is one of the best ways to improve in your score, but only if you pay close attention to where you made mistakes (even if it appears to just be a word misread, look for any patterns). That’s all I can think of in this moment, hope something helps!

As an SAT teacher and tutor, naturally I’m a big fan of taking a class or hiring a tutor, but, to be honest, going from a 650 to a 700 isn’t that big a leap, so you probably don’t need someone like me. As Nathan Chiu’s answer says, take more practice tests. Importantly, don’t just take them—review them. Look at every math question you missed, and ask yourself why. If there was a rule or math fact that you didn’t know, learn it. If you made a careless mistake, watch out for that sort of thing, and consider whether you were rushing through that question. If you got snared by one of ETS’ tricks, look at what they did and why you fell for it. If you don’t know why you got something wrong, ask someone for help. A 50 point improvement should be pretty attainable. Thanks for the A2A.

Get good with your calculator. Your calculator is your best friend on the calculator portion. Can’t solve linear equations accurately? Use matrix functions. Forget how to calculate standard deviation? 1-variable stats. Out of time to find an equation? 2-variable stats and graph. You can also check most answers, if you need to.Khan Academy. I don’t actually use the SAT prep! Instead, I’ve gone through and done every single exercise up until the end of Trigonometry. (I’ve also watched all of the videos for Algebra 2, Trigonometry, and Precalculus.)I scored a 36 on the math section of the ACT and a 740 on the SAT. Good luck!

Practice tests are the way to go. Make sure to simulate the test environment as best as you can. Set a timer for yourself. The SAT math section is about recognizing patterns and tricks. The best way to gain this skill is by looking at past exams and building this mathematical intuition. I've taken dozens of practice SAT exams prior to taking the SATs and I eventually got an 800 in math. Practice diligently and you can boost your scores.

Take SAT Official practices tests, published by College Board, one by one and try completing all of them. This gives you practice to remain concentrated for full exam duration and also help you in bridging the knowledge gap. Concentration also plays vital role in increasing the score. Practice makes you perfect. Take the most recent one, answer as if you are doing in a test center and within the prescribed time. Evaluate your answers, you have scoring sheet and also explanations to answers available. Review all wrong / guessed questions and understand how you can get them right next time. Adopt this iterative approach, until you complete all official tests and will definitely improve your overall score.

If you can’t afford a class, then buy the book on Online Shopping for Electronics, Apparel, Computers, Books, DVDs & more for under $20 and do all the practice tests. Practice, practice, practice. Khan Academy online is great for math. Lots of help there.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Bruno Fulco Mancini

response.answer_text: A good SAT course can help you succeed in your exam and score more. I would recommend taking an online course that offers premium online learning tools and high-stakes exam preparation solutions.
